Q28: R is not awful in any way, but the relatively low resources compared to other major languages. {cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}This is certainly not a criticism of those that devote their time to improving R. (Quite the opposite; without them, R would be far less powerful.){cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}However, R seems to be constantly tantalising me with issues that it will address in the future. While Im sure that this is true with every language, it seems particularly prevalent with R, and I sense that this is because R collectively has lower developer bandwidth than other languages. RStudio in particular has helped a lot, and I see the R Consortium making good strides, but it would be great to see more. After all, R has succeeded so much recently that it should see itself as a major language and resource itself accordingly. {cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}One idea in this area is whether the R Consortium could go the Wikipedia route and offer the R community the chance to fund its work in a small way (ie $5 per month, etc). If this funding went to the projects that were currently being considered, then Id be happy to contribute charitable $s (or, in my case, £s). (Id also welcome projects like making ggplot2 interactive and pipeable in a robust and consistent way; improving blogdown and htmlwidgets; and enabling more complex database joins and queries to compete with SQL.)

Q28: The type system. Too many cases of implicit casting (for lack of a better term). One of the worst examples is that drop=TRUE by default when slicing a matrix. If you grab two rows, it returns a matrix. If you grab only one row, it turns into a vector with no warning. This creates a lot of work when writing programs, and I get questions like this all the time from newbies. They have no clue why their code doesn't work, and to be honest, they shouldn't understand why their code doesn't work. This is far from the only example. It's like C on steroids with respect to silently changing the type of R objects.

I implemented the proposed solution/algorithm immediately. Q28: I have to plan my workshop curriculum very, very carefully when working with students.  I have three kinds of students: 1), undergraduates who are just trying to survive college and their statistics class, 2), faculty who will be buried with either the Excel manual or the SPSS manual in their cold, dead hands, and 3), clients who don't care what the process/algorithm was--they just want implementable results.{cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}Figuring out exactly what to teach undergraduates about R is a really, really hard problem.  See:{cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}http://varianceexplained.org/r/teach-tidyverse/{cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}for a summary and discussion.{cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}So my hardest part is very carefully picking out the right pieces for really, really, elementary (but motivated) learners--mosaic package, simple ggplot2, ease in dplyr, prefix all objects with their type (e.g., df.data, v.sex, s.flag, etc.)  R is just too powerful to be taught easily.  That's my hardest problem--helping real beginners learn and not be frustrated.

Q28: The naming of arguments and functions is up to the packages developer, so they are sometimes inconsistent. You have to check the documentation often not to get bitten by these. For example, after 17 years of use, I still sometimes mix up the arguments in the write.table (there is argument header in read.table, argument col.names in write.table and function colnames...). R documentation can sometimes be terse, but it usually is spot on, once you get used to reading it. For example, if the documentation says a function takes a matrix, it is not any table-like object, it is a matrix. Still, teaching R with the kind of documentation R has built-in is sometimes slightly painful.

Finding the right package!  There can be such a thing as too many packages & CRAN qualifies I think.  CRAN package popularity/usage is basically a very sharp power law distribution with only a handful that are used regularly and a very long tail of obscure packages. Do all these academic "one off" packages written for a specific paper or book have to be on CRAN? I think not.{cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}Many smaller utility packages containing only a few functions could also be consolidated into large packages.  I think the tidyverse is a very positive evolution in this regard and should be taken even further.{cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}The name of many packages is also terrible: MASS, CARS,...  Acronymys of book titles/paper titles is not a good name. Also "cute" names with an R in there somewhere aren't my cup of tea: I prefer "boring" but clear names.  E.g. "pipe" instead of magrittr (to decipher the name you have to know that it comes from the painting "Ceci n'est pas une pipe" by Magritte).{cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}Package content should not be organized according to code from books/reports/papers/project but according to topics/domains.{cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}R packages should get hierachical name (spaces)/path  & CRAN should be organized hierarchically according to broad topics/domains.{cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}Also there should be a strict private/public mechanism for functions in packages and names clashes from exported functions should be an error, not an obscure warning, which should be resolved by giving the fully qualified name (= with package name)
Not generally accepted in industry to use to put code in production

Q27: Future proofing my data analytics skills.

Two things jump out at users defecting from SPSS or another "major" commercial software package.  One, R output can be customized to include only the needed statistics.  I have generated 100-page "canned" analysis outputs in SPSS when the relevant statistical information could have been contained in 10 pages or less.  Two, R graphics are an order of magnitude better than SPSS, SAS, or Stata graphics.  Publication-quality plots can be obtained directly within R, without any post-processing with standalone graphics packages.
Q28: Error messages in R are frequently useless or even worse, misleading.  I know that error documentation is not high on any package developer's to-do list, but discovering the true cause of failure in syntax code is frequently frustrating to the end user.  I have said nasty things in this survey about SPSS, SAS, and Stata, but I will say that their error message reporting is superior to R.

While the "Tidyverse" contributions to R are excellent, and I use them constantly, and have enormously improved the usability of R, the fact that they evolve fairly quickly means that I feel like I'm constantly starting over on the R coding learning curve. Q28: Two worst aspects are continuation of its best features:{cr}{newline}1) Redundancy. Pretty much everything can be in more than one way. That's good bc it helps accommodate different programing styles but then it is easy to mix those different approaches up, which leads to annoying (although easy to fix) grammar errors. A simple example would be the alternative ways to reference components of data frames.{cr}{newline}2) Lack of regulation in the package-sphere. It's what lets us have a package for every little thing that you could think about but the lack of any protocol will lead to ecological catastrophe: it would take more time to sift through similar packages  of unclear quality than to write stuff from scratch. I'm not arguing for a wall around CRAN but some kind of coordinated, probably crowd-sourced effort to test and review everything that is submitted to CRAN. Then maybe a requirement that a package is accepted for review if it meets certain criteria re quality of documentation and availability of a working demo that can be used to assess what it is doing.

Q27: The community. There are so many people using R in data science, statistics, and applied fields that I can virtually always find packages to do complex tasks and support for bugs and coding issues. R is also the default platform for releases in my fields (statistics, sociology) so new methods seen in publications are typically ready for me to use. I teach a graduate level R programming course, and, I tell my students, any issue you encounter or problem you need to solve in R is probably solved and well documented online (if you know what to look for). That is a function of a large and mature user base.
Q28: Fragmentation and inconsistent development. Because R packages are products of the community, there are a bajillion of them, their quality is uneven, and development can stop abruptly at any time. Sometimes there are a dozen different packages available that handle the same types of problem and it their methods for doing so are very different. Choosing one approach can sometimes lock you in, which is unfortunate if you discover you need some unimplemented functionality down the road. Sometimes great packages have nonsensical syntax and poor documentation. Sometimes a great package hasn't been updated in years and there is not a solid replacement for it.

Q28: Oh dear, quite a bit.  The documentation quite often, the lofty and sometimes hostile style on r-help (though this has improved a bit and I can sympathise as so many questions are problematical).  However, the real challenge is that the learning curve is, mostly inevitably I think, steep and goes on being steep.  That isn't helped by real inconsistencies in style across packages and in the emergence of the tidyverse and magrittr conventions which sometimes seem to be taking R into being something so different from "old R" that they might be  a new language/system.  There are also some "gotchas", particularly around factors, but more widely, that can be really irritating and sometimes the get me with warnings or error messages that are way, way less than helpful, sometimes avoidably I think.  I think it might need a radical rethink of the warning/error system to make it easier to, and to encourage authors, to write much more helpful error messages.   I have a continued beef that R base neglected text output, except for those who used TeX in a way that I think was blatantly about keeping "ordinary" and social sciences from adopting R as early as they could have done and was completely inconsistent with the superb attention to graphic output.  A funny "verse" of knitr, Rstudio and a number of related packages, is starting to address this and so much so that I have, with some regrets, abandoned my beloved Emacs/ESS use of R for Rstudio.  However, there is much that is still a mess in table output and easy preparation of "from data to submitted paper" reproducible research.

Q28: Inconsistencies that arise because of the open-source nature of the language. Argument names and positions are often not consistent between functions. Naming conventions have changed: some functions now have arguments that use my.arg and my_arg in the same function. I don't see any reason for going for _ all of a sudden. If I need to use Python I need to remember to start counting from 0 instead of 1. If a Python person uses R s/he can remember that a . is not an operator. Maybe R should just set its own standards instead of following.{cr}{newline}{cr}{newline} It can be too flexible so that teaching R is hard. {cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}I would like to see base R being updated in some cases instead of the new functionality being added to packages. optim() is one case in point. John Nash points out that the routines in the optimx package should always be preferred. Why can't we just have these added to optim()?{cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}Maybe R core should consider breaking some code dependencies by revamping some deficiencies in the way that Python 2 differs from Python 3. Not sure how wise this would be, but I think we can learn from the Python case. {cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}I am also annoyed by how packages sometimes reinvent things that weren't broken, such as some aspects of the "tidyverse".{cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}The thing about packages is that the author gets the credit and possibly a citation. Contributing to the core language is much less visible. Should something be done about this to encourage more contributions along these lines?

I can't identify a single best aspect. There are multiple aspects of R that I greatly appreciate. I guess my top two would be:{cr}{newline}1) Flexibility: I can use CRAN/github packages or write my own code{cr}{newline}2) I really love rmarkdown and the ability to generate reports easily. When I need to discuss specific issues with analyses or data cleaning/management with my team, this makes it super-easy to pull in examples of those issues, maybe add some illustrative plots, and kick it off for their review. Doing something similar in SAS (our team's other primary tool) would require exporting results to multiple documents and hand-editing.

It's still not exactly simple; the variable scoping can be confusing when developing my own functions. And sometimes packages throw errors for no discernable reason.{cr}{newline}{cr}{newline}Also, the package documentation needs to have more and better examples, and better descriptive content. They seem to often take a bare-bones approach that is not sufficient for users who don't live and breathe R. Thank god for blogs and StackOverflow, honestly.
